en.title: üõ∞ Background connections in React Native: geolocation, websockets, and their quirks
en.shortDescription: Since 2021, I have repeatedly had to keep connections alive in the background in React Native. Here is what goes wrong with geolocation and WebSockets on iOS and Android, and how I handled it.
en.content:
Since 2021, I have regularly faced the same React Native challenge: keep a connection alive in the background without killing the battery or fighting too much with iOS and Android limitations.

This applied to background geolocation (for example, live tracking like delivery or ride‚Äëhailing), long‚Äëlived WebSockets (chat, streaming, live updates), and simple periodic background fetches.

To practice, I built a small pet project with use-background-events and use-intensive-background-events hooks in the react-native-background-fetching repo, where I tried different approaches to background work: from periodic background fetch to more intensive scenarios with frequent updates.

The goal: what needs to work in background

Most of the time, the requirements fell into three buckets:

  • Background geolocation: receive coordinates even when the app is minimized or the screen is locked.
  • Long‚Äëlived WebSockets: get messages or status updates in real time while the user is not actively in the app.
  • Periodic sync: every N minutes, pull fresh data from the backend and store it locally so that the app opens with up‚Äëto‚Äëdate state.

On paper, it sounds easy: ‚Äújust keep the connection running in the background‚Äù, but mobile OSes strongly disagree ‚Äî they aggressively save battery and kill anything that does not look critical.

Background geolocation: expectations vs reality

Background geolocation was the first pain point. On Android it feels more predictable: if you configure services and permissions correctly, you can get fairly frequent updates while the app is in the background.

On iOS things are stricter: the system tightly controls how often updates arrive and may batch several locations with a delay of a few minutes, especially when the device is stationary.

  • On Android I had to watch permissions like ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION and ACCESS_BACKGROUND_LOCATION, and sometimes run a foreground service with a persistent notification so the system would not kill the process.
  • On iOS it is crucial to configure Background Modes ‚ñ∏ Location updates and request Always permission; otherwise reliable background geolocation simply does not happen.

For production use cases I typically relied on mature native libraries such as react-native-background-geolocation, while my hooks acted as a thin abstraction on top and as a playground for experiments.

WebSockets in background: why things break

With WebSockets the story is even more interesting. When the React Native app is in the foreground, it is straightforward: create a WebSocket, subscribe to onopen, onmessage, onclose, and let the TCP connection live.

As soon as the app goes to the background, the picture changes: the JS runtime can be suspended, the connection dropped, and events stop reaching your handlers even if the socket still appears ‚Äúconnected‚Äù.

  • On Android you can keep the socket alive longer by moving it into a foreground service and doing the work outside the suspended JS runtime.
  • On iOS any attempt to maintain a ‚Äúforever alive‚Äù socket hits the reality that the OS will happily freeze the app, so you either embrace reconnect logic or pivot to push notifications and periodic fetch.

In one Uber‚Äëlike tracking scenario, the WebSocket connection on iOS could die after just a few minutes in the background, and the only realistic solution was accepting that and building robust reconnection and state restoration around it instead of chasing a perfectly persistent socket.

How Android and iOS differ in background

For myself, I ended up with a few core differences between the platforms when it comes to background behavior.

Aspect Android iOS
JS in background Can execute code longer via foreground services or headless tasks; the system is more tolerant of background work. JS is frozen quickly; background execution windows are limited, and the platform pushes you towards system mechanisms (background modes, push, fetch).
Geolocation Intervals and accuracy are configurable; with proper permissions, updates can be quite frequent. The system may batch locations and deliver them with delay, especially in stationary mode, and aggressively optimizes for battery.
WebSockets Can be kept alive in a foreground service; without it, the connection often dies when the app is backgrounded. A truly long‚Äëlived socket is an exception; it is more realistic to assume frequent disconnects and lean on reconnect and push notifications.
Background fetch react-native-background-fetch allows periodic tasks, and Android tends to be more generous with how often they run. The system decides how often to wake your app, and the real interval can be much larger than the theoretical 15 minutes.
Overall strategy Often you can ‚Äúkeep something alive‚Äù at the cost of a foreground notification and careful battery management. It is better to design architecture around OS events from day one and assume frequent stops and restarts.

How I approached reconnect and data freshness

Across most projects I had to start from the assumption that the connection will drop ‚Äî the only question is when and how often.

So instead of obsessing over a perfectly persistent link, the core of the design was predictable recovery: bring the connection back, fetch a fresh snapshot of state, sync local data, and only then resume the event stream.

  • At the WebSocket level this looked like a simple state machine: disconnected ‚Üí connecting ‚Üí connected ‚Üí reconnecting with exponential backoff and a limit on retry attempts.
  • After a successful reconnect I always made a separate request for the current server state (positions, messages, etc.), and treated incoming socket events as incremental updates rather than the single source of truth.
  • For periodic tasks I used react-native-background-fetch: it wakes the app for a short window where you can sync data or trigger reconnect logic.

In my React Native hooks this became a unified abstraction over ‚Äúbackground events‚Äù: externally just callbacks and flags, internally layers of guards, timeouts, and platform checks.

How the pet project helped

The pet project with use-background-events and use-intensive-background-events was designed as a sandbox: a safe place to drop connections, tweak intervals, turn off the network, and see what actually happens on a real device.

There I played with two main strategies:

  • A gentle mode: sparse background fetch callbacks and soft reconnects when the user returns to the app.
  • An intensive mode: frequent updates and aggressive reconnects for delivery‚Äë and tracking‚Äëlike cases, fully aware that this costs more battery and demands stricter native setup.

Over time this shaped a stable mental model for me: mobile background work is not about ‚Äúeternal connections‚Äù, but about respecting platform limits, having a solid recovery strategy, and being honest with the product team that there is no magic here without trade‚Äëoffs.

en.title: üß± Blockchain in plain terms: how it works, why it exists, and where multi-chain wallets fit
en.shortDescription: In November 2025, after working on a project involving NFC cards and a multi-chain wallet, I gave a talk to spread crypto fundamentals. This is a rewritten version: from blockchain basics to how multi-chain wallets work in practice.
en.content:
In November 2025, I gave an internal talk about crypto. The trigger was very practical: right before that I worked on a project involving NFC cards and a multi-chain wallet, and I wanted to lay out the fundamentals in a way that would make sense for newcomers.

The goal was simple: explain how things work (no magic), and at the end show what working with crypto looks like in practice. I won‚Äôt include hands-on snippets here for security reasons ‚Äî but you can find baseline examples in library docs and RPC API documentation.

Why blockchain was needed in the first place

It helps to start with a typical centralized application. Classic architecture has:

  • a client (app or website),
  • a server,
  • a single source of truth ‚Äî a database on the server.

The client sends requests, the server processes them, and returns responses. Everything lives in one place ‚Äî convenient, but it comes with fundamental downsides.

Problems of centralized systems

  • Single point of failure. If the data center goes down, the service goes down for everyone.
  • Censorship and access control. One server is easy to control or block.
  • Trust in the operator. Data physically belongs to whoever owns the infrastructure, and third-party access is always possible in theory.

Those problems naturally lead to the idea of decentralized applications.

What a decentralized application is

In a decentralized system there is no single central server. Instead:

  • there are many nodes,
  • each node stores a copy of the data,
  • participants are peers.

If one node goes offline, the network keeps working and data can be recovered from neighbors. A good analogy is torrents: one peer disappears and you can still download from others.

Blockchain is an evolution of this idea with additional integrity guarantees.

Blockchain: the basic structure

A blockchain is a chain of blocks linked together. Each block contains:

  • a list of transactions,
  • a timestamp,
  • the previous block hash,
  • its own hash.

The previous block hash is the key: change an old block and you invalidate the hashes of everything after it. That‚Äôs why the chain becomes effectively immutable, and all nodes must share the same history.

The main question: how the network agrees

With thousands of participants, you need a rule for which block is ‚Äúnext‚Äù. That‚Äôs what consensus algorithms do. I usually explain two popular ones.

Proof of Work (PoW)

PoW is the classic approach Bitcoin ran on for a long time. In short:

  • miners compete to solve a computational puzzle,
  • the first solver adds the next block,
  • they earn rewards and fees.

Why it‚Äôs secure: to rewrite history you‚Äôd need more computing power than the majority of the network. In practice that means huge hardware and electricity costs ‚Äî making attacks prohibitively expensive.

Downside: PoW is energy-hungry, which clashes with today‚Äôs environmental expectations.

Proof of Stake (PoS)

PoS reduces energy usage. Instead of miners, there are validators:

  • a validator locks up funds (stakes),
  • confirms block correctness,
  • earns rewards.

If a validator tries to cheat, their stake is slashed. To attack the network you‚Äôd need to control a large fraction of all staked funds ‚Äî losing that capital makes the attack economically irrational.

Fees and transaction speed

Users pick a transaction priority via fees:

  • lower fee ‚Üí typically slower inclusion,
  • higher fee ‚Üí typically faster inclusion.

Validators/miners naturally process the most profitable transactions first, so fees can swing widely depending on network load.

Addresses, keys, and cryptography

Blockchains rely on asymmetric cryptography:

  • public key ‚Äî commonly treated as your address,
  • private key ‚Äî your signature and control over funds.

A transaction is signed with the private key. Anyone can verify the signature, but they can‚Äôt forge it. And yes ‚Äî you should never share your private key.

Mnemonic phrase

To avoid dealing with long raw keys, wallets use a mnemonic phrase (seed phrase): 12 / 18 / 24 words from a fixed dictionary.

From a single phrase you can recover private keys and addresses. The number of combinations is so massive that brute forcing is effectively impossible.

Important: losing the mnemonic phrase means losing access to your funds.

Hot vs cold wallets

I frame this as a trade-off between convenience and security.

Hot wallet

  • private key stored in an app or on a server,
  • fast and convenient,
  • less secure.

Common on exchanges and in trading setups.

Cold wallet

  • key stored offline,
  • maximum security,
  • less convenient.

The ideal is combining hot-wallet UX with cold-wallet security. In practice that often means hybrid models and external confirmation flows ‚Äî details depend on product design and threat model.

Smart contracts

Blockchains can store not just transactions but also code. A smart contract is a program that:

  • executes inside the blockchain,
  • is transparent,
  • cannot be changed after deployment.

Smart contracts enable tokens (ERC-20), NFTs (ERC-721), DeFi, games, betting mechanisms, and more.

Why blockchain is transparent (but not necessarily personal)

Anyone can inspect blocks, transactions, and contract code. ‚ÄúAnonymity‚Äù typically comes from the fact that addresses are not inherently tied to real-world identities ‚Äî not from hiding data.

Multi-chain: why it matters

One thing that often surprises people: blockchains are not interconnected by default. Ethereum, Bitcoin, Tron ‚Äî separate chains.

Even a popular asset like USDT can exist across multiple networks as different contracts.

That‚Äôs why multi-chain wallets matter. They allow you to:

  • use one mnemonic phrase,
  • work across multiple blockchains,
  • have different addresses on different networks.

Technically, what changes is the derivation path ‚Äî the path used to derive keys and addresses from the seed phrase.

Multi-chain wallet architecture (how I internalized it)

A modern multi-chain wallet doesn‚Äôt necessarily need its own backend. In practice, it often:

  • connects via public RPC nodes,
  • uses external APIs for balances and prices,
  • implements fallback providers (if one fails, switch to another).

In a sense, this makes the app itself more ‚Äúdecentralized‚Äù infrastructure-wise: fewer single points of failure, more resilience via redundancy.

Wrap-up

My summary from the talk:

  • Blockchain is about removing a central authority, adding cryptographic integrity guarantees, and enabling transparency/verifiability.
  • Multi-chain is the next logical step: less fragmentation, better UX, and a more unified wallet experience.

That‚Äôs the foundation modern crypto wallets and many Web3 apps build upon. And for me, this talk helped lock in the ‚Äúskeleton‚Äù of the topic so it‚Äôs easier to reason about details later: keys, signatures, RPC, fees, resilience, and security.

en.title: üß™ Practicing Web Worker vs SharedWorker with a Pet Project: two small repos and what stuck
en.shortDescription: In March 2025, I built two tiny pet projects to get hands-on experience with Web Worker and SharedWorker and make the differences easier to remember.
en.content:
I have a personal habit: whenever I‚Äôm curious about a technology I haven‚Äôt used in commercial projects yet, I build a small pet project. That way the theory doesn‚Äôt evaporate ‚Äî I touch the API, see real browser behavior, and the mental model becomes much more stable.

In March 2025, I wanted to compare Web Worker and SharedWorker in practice. On paper it‚Äôs clear, but I wanted to actually see: when the UI blocks, how messaging feels, and what ‚Äúone worker per tab‚Äù vs ‚Äúone worker shared across tabs‚Äù looks like.

So I built two tiny repos:

  • AntonMoldakov/web-worker ‚Äî a simple demo showing main-thread blocking vs moving computation into a dedicated worker.
  • AntonMoldakov/shared-worker ‚Äî a demo where two pages share state through a SharedWorker and ports.

Goal and structure

The goal was intentionally practical: two small examples that you can open in the browser and understand with your eyes.

Web Worker: one page, a ‚Äúheavy‚Äù operation, and a UI button that clearly shows whether the main thread is blocked.

SharedWorker: two HTML pages (two tabs) connected to the same worker, sharing state through ports.

Pet project #1: Dedicated Web Worker

In web-worker I built a minimal ‚Äúvisual test‚Äù for UI blocking.

  • Clicking Calculate sum blocks the main thread, so Change background doesn‚Äôt respond while the calculation runs.
  • Clicking Calculate sum in Web Worker keeps the main thread responsive, so Change background still works while the worker does the work.

For me, this is the simplest way to ‚Äúfeel‚Äù why dedicated workers matter: you move the heavy task off the UI thread and the page stays interactive. That matches the classic worker messaging approach from the docs.

Pet project #2: SharedWorker across tabs

In shared-worker, I focused on the shared state idea across tabs.

  • Click update state on one page ‚Äî the other one reflects the update too.

The key thing I wanted to internalize: a SharedWorker is a single worker per origin, and it communicates with each page through ports, also the core differences (threads, messaging, lifecycle, cross-tab sync).

Also, a handy debugging detail I keep around now: inspecting shared workers in Chrome via chrome://inspect/#workers.

What this practice gave me

The main value isn‚Äôt ‚Äúproving‚Äù anything ‚Äî it‚Äôs having two small, working references I can revisit quickly:

  • When I need to demonstrate main-thread blocking vs worker execution ‚Äî I open web-worker.
  • When I need to refresh how ports and shared state look across tabs ‚Äî I open shared-worker.

That‚Äôs exactly why I like this format: a tiny pet-project, minimal scaffolding, maximum real browser behavior.

en.title: ü§ñ AI-First Engineering: How We Integrated AI into Development from 2023 to 2025
en.shortDescription: Hands-on experience of adopting AI in engineering workflows: from early research as a team lead to a systematic AI-first approach as a CTO.
en.content:
We started actively integrating AI into our development and engineering processes back in 2023. At that time, I was working as a team lead, and in November 2023 our CTO asked me to research existing AI agents, IDE integrations, and possible real-world use cases.

Even then, it was clear that AI was more than just autocomplete or smart search. It was becoming a full-fledged productivity tool capable of accelerating routine and semi-routine tasks.

Fast forward to 2025 ‚Äî now in the role of CTO, I continue pushing this direction forward. We:

  • measure effectiveness,
  • apply an AI-first approach,
  • run internal talks,
  • share real-world findings during weekly syncs.

Below are several practical AI use cases that we started using heavily in 2025.

1. Layouting with MCP + Figma

For UI layouting, we connected an MCP server to both the IDE and Figma.

The main insight: AI output quality depends heavily on Figma hygiene. To get good results, you need:

  • properly named frames,
  • design tokens and variables,
  • clean and predictable structure.

When done right, AI produces layout code that‚Äôs surprisingly close to production-ready.

2. Screenshot-to-code is better than expected

One of the most unexpected discoveries was screenshot-to-code.

In many cases, AI produces better layout results from screenshots than from MCP. Most likely because:

  • there‚Äôs no nested frame noise,
  • no excessive layout metadata,
  • no over-specified styles.

The model focuses purely on visual output and recreates it more cleanly.

3. Admin panels are a perfect AI target

Admin panels turned out to be one of the best AI use cases.

Especially when using React Admin:

  • great documentation,
  • lots of examples,
  • very predictable patterns.

The usual workflow:

  • provide a documentation link,
  • share openapi.json as an API contract,
  • describe business rules,
  • optionally request custom UI.

The result is a working admin panel built extremely fast.

4. SDK and complex library integrations

AI handles SDK and complex library integrations surprisingly well, especially when the library has:

  • solid documentation,
  • an active GitHub repository,
  • real usage examples.

A particularly useful pattern is asking AI to extract and adapt only a specific method or class, instead of pulling the entire dependency.

5. Language-to-language code conversion

Code conversion between languages is another area where AI shines.

One real case: rewriting an NFS-based library (connection, auth, read, write) from Python to JavaScript.

The AI handled it in one or two prompts, including adapting the logic to JavaScript‚Äôs async model.

What we use daily

Beyond these examples, AI is now a default tool for:

  • research and PoCs,
  • code analysis and refactoring,
  • automated tests,
  • AI-assisted IDE navigation,
  • utility and boilerplate generation.

Limitations and trade-offs

The main limitation so far is strict design requirements and precise acceptance criteria.

However, if your primary goal is business value rather than pixel-perfect accuracy, AI allows you to:

  • build MVPs significantly faster,
  • test hypotheses early,
  • dramatically improve time-to-market.

Conclusion

For us, AI is not hype ‚Äî it‚Äôs a practical engineering multiplier. It doesn‚Äôt replace developers, but it removes friction and frees time for real problem-solving.

Improving time-to-market ‚Äî isn‚Äôt that what really matters when validating a product?

en.title: üßë‚Äçüéì How We Redesigned Our Internal Internship: From New Tasks to a Complete Upgrade
en.shortDescription: A personal story of designing and fully refactoring an internal internship program: assignments, mentoring, filtering, and growing developers.
en.content:
I‚Äôve been involved several times in modernizing and improving our internal internship program. From the very beginning, it was aimed at students and junior developers who already understand basic data structures, JavaScript syntax, and logical building blocks, but haven‚Äôt yet experienced what real commercial development looks like in practice.

The core idea of the internship has always been simple: instead of abstract textbook problems, give people realistic, day-to-day development scenarios ‚Äî the exact kinds of tasks they will face during their first months on actual projects.

Fall 2022: the first major React Native assignment

In the fall of 2022, together with other mobile developers, I took part in designing a new assignment for React Native. It was a mobile app built as a small social network.

We intentionally packed it with as many typical mobile development pitfalls as possible:

  • splash screens,
  • complex navigation flows,
  • working with permissions,
  • forms, keyboard handling, and focus management,
  • gallery access,
  • light and dark themes.

The result was a relatively small application, but one that was densely filled with real-world problems. For an experienced developer, it wasn‚Äôt particularly challenging. For an intern, however, it was a concentrated set of exactly the kinds of tasks they would be doing early on in real projects.

What‚Äôs especially nice is that we even kept the initial UI sketch, which later evolved into a full-fledged design.

Why this kind of assignment works

The main value of projects like this is that interns are not learning in a vacuum. They:

  • run into non-obvious problems,
  • learn how to read and rely on documentation,
  • start to see how features affect each other,
  • get used to real platform constraints.

In essence, it‚Äôs a simulation of the first months on the job ‚Äî but in a controlled and safe environment.

Fall 2024: a full internship refactor

By the fall of 2024, already in the role of CTO, I was responsible for a complete refactor of the internship program. We rebuilt it from the ground up ‚Äî from structure to selection logic.

As a result, we ended up with the system we use today:

  1. Internship for web React developers
  2. Internship for mobile React Native developers
  3. Internship for mobile Flutter developers
  4. Internship for backend NestJS developers

How frontend internships are structured

The frontend tracks (Flutter, React, React Native) consist of five assignments.

The first two assignments are relatively simple. At this stage, interns:

  • get familiar with the framework,
  • learn core libraries,
  • work with forms and state management.

These tasks come with a technical specification, but without strict design requirements and without an API.

The third and fifth assignments are full-scale projects:

  • there is a design that must be followed,
  • there is an API to integrate with,
  • and architecture matters.

This is where developers get hands-on experience with Clean Architecture in Flutter and FSD in React and React Native.

The fourth assignment is an admin panel. We usually use React Admin ‚Äî a fast and practical solution for building standard admin dashboards, exactly the kind that appears frequently in real-world projects.

Backend internship

The backend internship is built as a single project, but logically split into microservices:

  • authentication service,
  • online surveys service,
  • personal finance management service,
  • inventory management service.

Each service comes with a clear and detailed specification, which allows us to evaluate not only code quality, but also the ability to read requirements and design solutions.

Mentorship, filtering, and hiring

Throughout the entire internship, each intern is accompanied by a mentor. Mentors have around 3 hours per week dedicated to:

  • code reviews,
  • sync calls,
  • detailed feedback.

The internship lasts about two months. During this time, weaker or problematic candidates naturally drop off. Those who successfully complete the program can be recommended by mentors for hiring.

I personally conduct the technical interviews with these candidates. They‚Äôre not overly difficult ‚Äî my goal is to understand:

  • how well the material was absorbed,
  • how the candidate reasons about problems,
  • and their soft skills.

The best of the best are happily brought on board, and from there we continue growing them through our internal grading system. But that‚Äôs a story for another time.

Conclusion

For me, this internship is not just an educational program ‚Äî it‚Äôs a tool for shaping strong engineers. It allows us to fairly and safely evaluate how a person handles real-world tasks and gives interns a clear picture of what commercial development is actually like.

And for the team, it‚Äôs one of the most effective ways to find motivated, already well-prepared developers.

en.shortDescription: How the OpenAPI codegen + MSW + Orval combination streamlined our workflow and became my go-to frontend engineering pattern.
en.content:
Once a week I run an internal meeting for our frontend leads ‚Äî a kind of technical club where we share tools, discuss tricky cases from projects, and present small internal tech talks. At one of these meetings, in late 2024, one of the most proactive leads brought an idea: ‚ÄúTry Orval + MSW. It‚Äôs worth it.‚Äù

We experimented with it, tried it on real tasks ‚Äî and I was genuinely impressed. After a couple of weeks in production, I made a personal rule: . I now recommend this setup to every team.

The initial setup takes roughly one working day. We've been using OpenAPI codegen for a long time already, and this setup immediately gives you all the usual ‚Äî and extremely valuable ‚Äî benefits: no more manually writing types or endpoints, no more chasing schema changes, and TypeScript instantly highlights contract mismatches.

And best of all: you can switch between real API and fully typed mock API with a single environment variable. This saved us countless times ‚Äî especially when backend was unstable or still under development by another team.

Why this setup works so well

The OpenAPI codegen + MSW + Orval trio provides major benefits:

  • automatic generation of API clients and TypeScript types;
  • instant contract validation through TypeScript;
  • mocks generated from the same OpenAPI schema ‚Üí guaranteed consistency;
  • real/mock switching via a single env variable;
  • frontend development becomes independent from backend readiness;

en.title: üß™ Practicing WebAssembly Through a Pet Project: AssemblyScript, Benchmarks, and Personal Experience
en.shortDescription: How I used a small pet project to solidify my understanding of WebAssembly and AssemblyScript in practice and generate my own benchmarks.
en.content:
I have a personal habit: whenever I get interested in a new technology that I haven‚Äôt yet used on commercial projects, I build a small pet project. It's the best way to lock in the theory ‚Äî it only really sticks once you run it through actual practice. So in March 2025, I finally decided to dive into WebAssembly for real.

I had studied the theory long ago, but never got any hands-on experience. I wanted to see the entire flow: write some code, compile it to wasm, load the module in the browser, call its functions from JavaScript, and compare their performance to native JS.

I chose AssemblyScript as the language. It‚Äôs very close to TypeScript, which makes the learning curve almost nonexistent. And as a bonus, it‚Äôs extremely convenient to first write code in JS/TS and then use AI to transform it into AssemblyScript. This saves a lot of time, especially when you're not yet fully familiar with AssemblyScript's specifics.

Project goal and structure

The idea was simple: implement identical functions in both JavaScript and AssemblyScript ‚Äî arithmetic, factorial, a few array operations ‚Äî run benchmarks, and compare them. I wanted my own numbers.

The project turned out compact: assembly/ contained AssemblyScript functions, the build was done via npm run asbuild, and then a minimal HTML page plus a JS loader that imports the wasm module and exposes its methods.

Benchmarks

The experiments were purely practical ‚Äî not meant to prove or disprove anything. I just wanted to see how things behave under real conditions.

‚óè Simple functions

In tasks like add(a, b), JavaScript turned out to be faster. The call overhead of a wasm function is larger than the operation itself ‚Äî totally expected.

‚óè Computationally heavy functions

For heavy tasks like factorial(n) with large inputs, WebAssembly performed noticeably faster. This is where low-level execution shows its strengths.

‚óè More complex structures: a merge-two-lists example

Things got especially interesting when I tried implementing a merge of two lists. On the JavaScript side, the data structure was trivial ‚Äî two arrays of numbers. But with WebAssembly, things were not so straightforward.

To pass a complex structure (for example, two arrays) into wasm, you have to:

  • manually allocate memory for each array,
  • copy the data from JS into wasm's memory,
  • pass pointers instead of arrays,
  • write helper functions both in JS and in AssemblyScript.

As a result, the ‚Äúmerge lists‚Äù experiment clearly showed that complex structures require more effort and resources to transfer between the JS and WASM worlds. It‚Äôs logical ‚Äî wasm works with linear memory rather than dynamic JS objects ‚Äî but experiencing this firsthand was especially valuable.

The merge itself runs fast inside wasm, but the data setup and reverse transformation back to JS take time. These details give a real understanding of how WebAssembly works under the hood.

What this experience gave me

The main outcome wasn‚Äôt the benchmarks, but the understanding of the process. When you build a wasm module manually, work with memory, imports, and exports, the technology becomes much clearer. Now I have a grounded sense of how WebAssembly behaves in a real environment ‚Äî a valuable skill that might come in handy in production tasks.

Pet projects like this help me learn new tools faster and more deeply. They‚Äôre small, but they give real experience ‚Äî something you can‚Äôt get from documentation alone.

Conclusion

The project was small but very useful. It became my personal practical base for understanding WebAssembly and AssemblyScript and helped solidify knowledge that previously existed only in theory. And it also expanded my collection of pet projects ‚Äî the ones I build specifically to explore new technologies without waiting for them to appear in commercial work.

en.title: üî• 100 Hours of Native Development: Integrating Yandex Ads into React Native
en.shortDescription: A story about how the lack of a ready-made library led to a deep dive into Native Modules, Fabric Components, and native layouting.
en.content:
In spring 2022, I was part of a team developing a mobile app using React Native. Due to a lack of other resources, I got the chance to work with native modules and components. Back then I had no idea I was in for more than 100 hours of fascinating development üòÖ

From Google Ads to an urgent migration to Yandex

The initial task seemed simple: ‚ÄúIntegrate Google Ads‚Äù ‚Äî our main monetization method. We already had a tested library and prior experience.

But unexpected external events forced us to urgently migrate to Yandex Ads. That‚Äôs when the adventure began.

At that moment Yandex had only one React Native library, and it was outdated. We checked it ‚Äî some parts worked, some didn‚Äôt. Later we refactored several pieces and reused them inside our project.

Four ad formats, three integrated

First we had to analyze the documentation and understand which ad types we needed to implement. Yandex offered four formats:

  • Rewarded Ad ‚Äî fullscreen ads with a reward for watching.
  • Banner ‚Äî a small static banner at the top or bottom of the screen.
  • Fullscreen ‚Äî fullscreen ads without rewards.
  • Native (now Feed) ‚Äî an in-content card styled to match the app.

We integrated three of them: Rewarded, Fullscreen, and the most intriguing ‚Äî Native.

First steps with native modules

Rewarded and Fullscreen ads were quite straightforward, even though this was my first experience with the native side of RN. We needed to create React Native Native Modules (official docs). TurboModules weren‚Äôt the default yet.

I quickly built a basic example, verified functionality on both iOS and Android, implemented the required methods, compiled the modules, and tested everything in RN. No major issues: essentially just calling native SDKs through the bridge, and the ads appeared on top of the UI without interacting with it.

Diving into Fabric Native Components: native ads

But Native Ads were far more interesting. According to the documentation, their display requirements were extremely strict: if conditions weren‚Äôt met, impressions would not be counted, directly impacting monetization.

What was required?

We had to embed a native ad card directly into the app feed ‚Äî and style it so it blended naturally with the rest of the list items. The feed used a masonry layout, looking something like this:

Sounds simple ‚Äî just lay out a card. But not really.

The first issue appeared immediately: the layout had to be fully native ‚Äî XML on Android, Storyboard/StoryboardKit on iOS. That was new to me, and it took quite some time to shape the cards properly.

But how to integrate all this into React Native? Back then there was almost no information on Native Components. The only useful resources I found were a Sbermarket article and a talk.

Today the documentation on Native Components is abundant. There are even ready-to-use examples on GitHub. If only we had that back then... link

The cards rendered fine: skeleton loader, ad loading‚Ä¶ but the joy didn‚Äôt last. Components began overflowing with content. First shock, then denial, then bargaining ‚Äî the full cycle üòÖ

Eventually it became clear: we had to compute dynamic card height. I ended up writing a function on the Fiber level to measure component size based on image dimensions and text line count ü§™.

After many iterations we finally achieved stable behavior for native ads. A couple of years later, an official React Native library was released ‚Äî but that's another story üôÇ

Summary

The Yandex Ads integration turned out to be a remarkable challenge: from initial work with Native Modules to deep exploration of Fabric Native Components and native layouting. Despite the complexity, the experience proved invaluable and offered a strong understanding of how React Native interacts with platform-level UI components.

en.title: ü™ñ Battle-Tested Experience with NFC Cards and MultiChain Wallets
en.shortDescription: Building NFC workflows, designing a scalable multichain wallet and leading a hybrid engineering team as a CTO.
en.content:
In the second half of 2025, I had the chance to work hands-on on a project that blended two domains rarely found in the same sentence: IoT and Web3. Despite a fairly busy CTO schedule, I wanted to stay involved technically ‚Äî and this project offered more than enough opportunities.

IoT: Getting NFC cards to behave

Together with a colleague, we tackled a full cycle of working with NFC cards: activating them, taking them out of transport mode, creating directories, configuring files with various access levels. I developed software that later served as a remote tool for factories in Russia and China. With its help, we processed more than five thousand NFC cards. By the end of it, I could almost tell what state a card was in just by the sound of the reader ‚Äî a skill that, surprisingly, is not yet listed on LinkedIn.

Web3: Designing a multichain wallet that grows without friction

The Web3 part of the project focused on designing the architecture of a scalable multichain wallet. The long-term goal was clear: support many networks without rewriting half the system each time. I manually implemented around ten networks myself and designed a unified approach for extending networks that run on the same virtual machine, such as EVM-compatible chains. I've achieved the point where networks running on a single VM can be added in a couple of hours.. Under my guidance, the team added support for nearly twenty networks, with a few more underway.

Management: Leading a hybrid team while wearing multiple hats

From a management standpoint, the project was just as interesting. As a CTO, I couldn‚Äôt be fully dedicated to development, so I assembled a mixed team of in-house engineers and project-based specialists. Over time, the composition changed ‚Äî which is normal for a growing project ‚Äî and eventually we arrived at a strong, well-balanced team with the right combination of technical and communication skills. When the structure solidified, I handed the project over to the team lead and shifted into a supervisory role.

Looking back, the project brought together engineering, architecture, coordination and a fair amount of cross-timezone problem solving. A demanding experience, but also one of the most rewarding.
